node.title: Making His Marathon Debut, With a Lot of Help From New Friends
node.alt: “The way that my body has felt for the marathon build has made me think I can do this for a lot longer,” Ben True said.
node.description: Ben True needed runners to train with him in New Hampshire, so he recruited some young talent.
node.content: ["HANOVER, N.H. \u2014 Ben True spent years training alone. A solitary figure on the roads and trails near his home here in Hanover, he logged long miles in pursuit of distance-running glory. It was not that he wanted to be doing everything by himself, without the help of a team. But New Hampshire \u2014 far from the running meccas of Boulder, Colo., or Flagstaff, Ariz. \u2014 is home for him.", "\u201cBeing here makes me happy,\u201d he said on a recent weekend afternoon. \u201cI\u2019m in my comfort zone. But would I have loved to have other people come train with me? Definitely.\u201d", "In recent months, ahead of his appearance in the New York City Marathon on Sunday, True decided to mix things up. After spreading word among friends that he would be willing to go so far as to pay someone to relocate and train with him, True, 35, now has two full-time running buddies \u2014 Dan Curts and Fred Huxham, both 25 \u2014 who have used True to feed their own ambitions in the sport.", "And he has organized a weekly long run: the Tour de Woodstock, just down the road in Vermont. True posts the time and location on Strava, an online exercise-tracking tool, and anyone is welcome to join. Consider it the running equivalent of Kevin Durant advertising his pickup basketball games on Twitter. True\u2019s weekend warriors are free to break off and do shorter, slower circuits. Everyone meets for coffee and waffles afterward.", "\u201cIt\u2019s a social thing,\u201d Huxham said. \u201cBut if you\u2019re going a long way with Ben, you\u2019ve got to be ready to pick up the pace.\u201d", "With a small community behind him, True is set for his marathon debut, nearly five months after he narrowly missed an Olympic berth in the 10,000 meters when he finished fourth at the United States trials. And while he has guarded against putting too much pressure on himself, he considers New York something of a test. A test, he said, to see whether he is \u201ccut out for the marathon.\u201d And a test to determine whether his future in the sport is financially viable.", "\u201cI\u2019d love to keep racing,\u201d he said. \u201cThe way that my body has felt for the marathon build has made me think I can do this for a lot longer.\u201d", "True, who grew up in Maine and graduated from Dartmouth, has history with New York. In 2015, he became the first American man to win a 5,000-meter Diamond League race, with a victory at the Adidas Grand Prix on Randalls Island. In 2018, he won the New York City Half Marathon in his debut at the distance.", "He chose to make his marathon debut in New York because of his strong relationship with New York Road Runners, which organizes the marathon, and his love of pure competition. Unlike several other major marathons, New York does not employ pacesetters. And on a notoriously challenging course, elite runners chase one another rather than the clock.", "On Sunday, he will face a loaded field including the likes of Kenenisa Bekele of Ethiopia, a four-time Olympic medalist and five-time world champion. True has never raced with a wristwatch, he said, but he plans to wear one for the marathon to protect himself from himself. He has some familiarity with the course, and knows how runners can surge at various points of the race, like Mile 16 off the Queensboro Bridge.", "\u201cI\u2019m somebody who thrives on latching onto somebody and never letting go,\u201d True said. \u201cBut if Bekele drops a 4:30 mile coming off the bridge, I probably shouldn\u2019t try to match him.\u201d", "True would like to exercise patience, a component of success that has occasionally been in short supply for him. He thought back to 2019, when he crammed his schedule full of races and competed in the 5,000 meters at the world championships with an Achilles\u2019 tendon injury. He should have taken time off, he said, but he was worried about losing his health insurance if his world ranking dipped.", "\u201cI was just in so much pain,\u201d he said, \u201cand it really made me think that I either had to step away or make some big changes. Luckily, Dan showed up.\u201d", "True had been circulating an unconventional offer in the high-end running community: He would pay someone $20,000 to run with him. He went a few years without any takers.", "\u201cI\u2019m not sure if people thought I was serious,\u201d he said.", "Curts, who ran at Iowa State, was back home in Maine when he learned from mutual friends that True was in the market for a training companion. He moved to New Hampshire last fall, then recruited Huxham, who was a second-team all-American at the University of Washington, to join them a couple of months ago.", "\u201cI have no idea how he ran alone for so long,\u201d Curts said. \u201cThere\u2019s a reason nobody at his level on the planet does that.\u201d", "On weekends, the three are joined by a motley crew of men and women \u2014 medical students and engineers, former cyclists and soccer players \u2014 on the roads near Woodstock. True said the experience as a whole had been energizing.", "\u201cI don\u2019t doubt that if I\u2019d had a training partner through my career, I would\u2019ve run faster,\u201d True said.", "At the same time, he has balanced training with fatherhood \u2014 he and his wife, Sarah True, an Olympic triathlete, have a 3-month-old son, Haakon \u2014 while coping with some of the harder realities of his profession. At the end of last year, Saucony chose not to renew his sponsorship deal after he had spent nearly 10 years with the company.", "\u201cI am not a social media influencer,\u201d said True, who has an Instagram account that mostly collects dust. \u201cI do not like using it.\u201d", "In New York, True said he would be wearing \u201cold\u201d Saucony sneakers and a blank singlet as an unsponsored athlete.", "True tends to frame his observations about marathon training as questions, which makes sense given his relative inexperience. He does not know what to expect. \u201cHopefully I\u2019m ready?\u201d he asked.", "Yet he has found marathon training to be more forgiving than the work he did to prepare for 5,000- and 10,000-meter races on the track: He does more mileage now, but less of the high-end speed work that often led to injuries. The result is that he feels surprisingly spry, which has made him wonder whether he is doing it right.", "\u201cEveryone always complains about how exhausted they are during marathon training,\u201d he said, \u201cand I haven\u2019t really experienced that?\u201d", "True understands, for example, that the course has its share of inclines, and he has done the bulk of his training on a quiet road that features hilly terrain. \u201cSo I\u2019m hoping that helps me out?\u201d he asked.", "Because True has not had much income this year, his $20,000 payment to Curts ended up being a one-time thing, but he has been coaching Curts and Huxham pro bono, in addition to running alongside them.", "The experience has been a thrill for Curts, who taped an autographed photograph of True to the front of his mileage log when he was a high school freshman.", "Huxham, who placed second at the national 10-kilometer road racing championships in July, has used True to gauge his own improvement. The bar, Huxham said, is high.", "He cited a recent 12-kilometer time trial that True ran on his own. Afterward, True looked as if he had gone for a brisk walk. Huxham checked True\u2019s splits. \u201cHe had come within 10 seconds of the national record,\u201d Huxham said.", "There have been long periods, True said, when running feels like a job to him, when the injuries seem unavoidable and the pain is real, and he asks himself: \u201cWhy am I doing this?\u201d", "Now is not one of those times, he said. He heads out the door with his friends feeling healthy and free, and runs toward something beautiful, a place he had help finding.", "\u201cThere\u2019s nothing better,\u201d he said."]
